Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Proposal: EAGER: Towards Real-time, High throughput Insect Behavior Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will develop an efficient method of analyzing a large quantity of animal behavior data collected in video. Animal behavior research is often limited by the large time investments needed to observe animal activities and extract quantitative information from this. Automating this process, in other words enabling a computer system to extract relevant information from videos of animal behavior, would result in radical time-saving for such studies. Not only that, but a system that would allow real-time analysis could enable researchers to change experiments mid-stream, as measurements of the behavior of observed individuals would become available immediately. This will allow a new level of control, and enable totally new experimental approaches. A tool will be developed to enable high-throughput, real-time analysis of insect behavior on a Desktop PC by fusing sophisticated image analysis software and powerful, rapidly developing Graphical Processor Unit (GPU) hardware technology. The tool will be affordable (about $10k/unit), easy-to-maintain (it's a PC) while providing a real-time, automated analysis of insect behavior increasing the throughput by up to 400 times. Ant colonies, one of the model organisms for which we will validate the tool, are uniquely suitable to demonstrate both sophistication and complexity of biological systems in outreach. In addition, graduate students will be provided interdisciplinary training through the project. Interdisciplinary research, in particular computer science-biology interactions, is the future, and this type of project will serve as a great training mechanism for the students. Most importantly, the developed tool will be disseminated to other researchers by making the software available for download through the project website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ant colonies seem to be quite efficient at achieving their goals as a group, even when individuals make errors and the environment changes rapidly. How can we, as humans, benefit from the ants' collective strategies? This would be useful not only in human organizations, but in other distributed or networked systems such as computer networks, power grids, and software.

In order to understand how ants achieve this efficiency and robustness, we need to be able to monitor and understand the activity and decision-making not just of the group as a whole, but the individuals that comprise it. This used to be painstaking and take a long time, as each individual ant needed to be painted with different colors and then followed around by a human watching a video of the ants' behaviors. Even existing image analysis was not accurate enough to be able to track similar-looking ants who were walking over and under each other in their nest environment.

The current project changed this completely, by allowing computer-assisted automated tracking of individually recognized ants on videos, at a high accuracy and speed. We can now follow each individual in an ant colony at high resolution, meaning that we can study how the particular local environment causes ants to make different decisions, how they interact with whom, and how this shapes the problem-solving abilities of the ant colony as a group.

We can now do fundamentally new things like comparing the shape of the network of interactions in ant colonies, human social groups, genetic and engineered networks, to study which aspects of network structure lead to fast, robust, or flexible information transmission. We can compare how different social groups solve problems differently, and whether this emerges from their different members or their different interaction strategies. We have already found that ant colonies have a surprising number of individuals that do not seem to do any work, and we can now study in detail whether this is actually optimal at the group level or a result of selfishness or inefficiency. We can understand whether differences between individuals or groups that we see are stable over time, or change with the environment, age, or social factors. We can now see how ant workers are spatially ordered in their nest, rather than randomly mixing: each individual has a specific area it returns to for resting, and this enables particular groups of individuals to maintain special connections.

All of these types of studies would have required a prohibitively large amount of investment (in manpower and time) prior to the development of our video tracking tool. We therefore expect a change in how behavioral science is done as a result of this project, from a discipline focused on short-term data collection on few individuals to long-term tracking of whole groups and comparisons between groups.

In addition to this impact on science, particularly the study of networks, collective organization, and animal behavior, the project has also significantly contributed to education by training many students and young researchers in skills necessary for project development and also in interdisciplinary research at the interface of computer science and biology. Last but not least, this project has helped dissemination of scientific knowledge to the public through multiple venues (an updated list is available here: http://socialinsectlab.arizona.edu/content/our-science-public-media).
